The order of a group $G$, denoted as ord $G$, is defined as the number of elements in $G$ if $G$ is finite. If $G$ is infinite, its order is said to be infinite.
A finite group G is called a p-group if the order of G is a power of p, where p is a prime number.
Does the concept of a/an Order of a group need to be defined for a definition of a/an p-group to make sense? (True if the first concept is needed and False if is not.)

Explanation: To determine whether a group G is a p-group, we need to know the order of G. According to the definition of a p-group, the group G is a p-group if its order is a power of a prime number p. This directly implies that we must be able to determine the order of G to check if it is a power of p. Without the concept of the order of a group, we would not be able to define or identify a p-group because we wouldn't know how many elements the group contains or whether that number is a power of a prime. Therefore, the concept of the order of a group is essential for the definition of a p-group to make sense.
